body_text:
So I just checked in Firefox's browser console using something like this:
let x = {foo: 5};
x = Object.freeze(x);
y = Cu.cloneInto(y, content) // this only works with e10s disabled
Object.isFrozen(y) // returns false
y.foo = 10; // changes y.foo
So I don't think this works as-is. :-(
If the event object is cloned into the sandbox, I wouldn't expect there to be issues with calling Object.freeze on it. What exactly happens if you try and freeze the object?
body:
So I just checked in Firefox's browser console using something like this:

```js
let x = {foo: 5};
x = Object.freeze(x);
y = Cu.cloneInto(y, content) // this only works with e10s disabled
Object.isFrozen(y) // returns false
y.foo = 10; // changes y.foo
```

So I don't think this works as-is. :-(

If the event object is cloned into the sandbox, I wouldn't expect there to be issues with calling `Object.freeze` on it. What exactly happens if you try and freeze the object?
body_html:
So I just checked in Firefox's browser console using something like this:

let x = {foo: 5};
x = Object.freeze(x);
y = Cu.cloneInto(y, content) // this only works with e10s disabled
Object.isFrozen(y) // returns false
y.foo = 10; // changes y.foo

So I don't think this works as-is. :-(

If the event object is cloned into the sandbox, I wouldn't expect there to be issues with calling Object.freeze on it. What exactly happens if you try and freeze the object?
